docs.lead_paragraph: Powerful drugs intended for people with severe mental illness are prescribed for children in foster care at a disturbingly high rate.

headline.seo: Study Finds Foster Children Often Given Antipsychosis Drugs
headline.main: Drugs Used for Psychotics Go to Youths in Foster Care
headline.print_headline: Drugs Used For Psychosis Go to Youths In Foster Care

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Pediatrics finds foster children are being prescribed cocktails of powerful antipsychosis drugs just as frequently as some of the most mentally disabled youngsters on Medicaid; Susan dosReis of the University of Maryland, study's lead author, says foster children are being given drugs despite fact that they do not exhibit complex medical issues, such as schizophrenia, for which they were developed.
docs.snippet: Powerful drugs intended for people with severe mental illness are prescribed for children in foster care at a disturbingly high rate.

docs.lead_paragraph: The agency said the drug “has not been shown to be safe and effective” for breast cancer patients, but would remain available for treating other types of cancer.

headline.main: F.D.A. Revokes Approval of Avastin for Use as Breast Cancer Drug
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Revokes Approval of Avastin for Use as Breast Cancer Drug

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration commissioner Dr Margaret A Hamburg revokes approval of Genentech drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer; cites clinical trials that have shown that drug was not effective and exposed patients to serious side effects; Avastin will remain available for treating other types of cancer and doctors can use it off-label to treat breast cancer, but insurers might not pay for it.
docs.snippet: The agency said the drug “has not been shown to be safe and effective” for breast cancer patients, but would remain available for treating other types of cancer.

headline.main: A Conversation Many Doctors Won't Have

docs.abstract: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.
docs.snippet: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.

docs.lead_paragraph: At Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island, where she's a medical director, Dr. Joan Teno has grown accustomed to patients being admitted with no clear understanding of their condition or prognosis. "The oncologist has told them, 'It's time to take a holiday from chemo,'" she said. "It's a way not to have a conversation he or she finds hard to do."

headline.main: A Conversation Many Doctors Won't Have

docs.abstract: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.
docs.snippet: What happens when elderly patients are told that death is imminent.

docs.lead_paragraph: An amendment redefining “personhood” was soundly rejected largely on fears that hinged on aspects of reproductive science other than abortion.

headline.seo: ‘No’ Vote in Mississippi Hinged on Issues Beyond Abortion
headline.main: Medical Nuances Drove ‘No’ Vote in Mississippi
headline.print_headline: Medical Nuances Drove ‘No’ Vote in Mississippi

docs.abstract: Many voters in Mississippi rejected anti-abortion amendment because of concerns that the definition of ‘personhood’ may have curtailed access to in vitro fertilization and birth control, or limited treatment for high-risk pregnancies.
docs.snippet: An amendment redefining “personhood” was soundly rejected largely on fears that hinged on aspects of reproductive science other than abortion.
